Package org.jglfont.spi

Interface JGLFontRenderer

public interface JGLFontRenderer
The interface necessary to let org.jglfont render a Bitmap. The actual resource loading of bitmap files needs to be done in here. org.jglfont acts as a provider of the glyph data and JGLFontRenderer implementations can use whatever way they seem fit to display this data. A single JGLFontRenderer can be used to render multiple fonts.

  • Method Details

    • registerBitmap

      void registerBitmap(String key, InputStream data, String filename) throws IOException
      Register the bitmap with the given data under the given key. This is a texture that contains all the font glyph data. It's not necessary that this call directly maps to a single actual texture since implementation can decide to pack multiple textures into a single one.
      Parameters:
      key - the key for this specific bitmap
      data - the inputstream to the data
      Throws:
      IOException

    • registerBitmap

      void registerBitmap(String key, ByteBuffer data, int width, int height, String filename) throws IOException
      Registers the bitmap with the given data in form of bytebuffer, having 32 bit per pixel layout (r,g,b,a)
      Parameters:
      key - the key for this specific bitmap
      data - the direct-allocated ByteBuffer having (R,G,B,A) pixel components
      width - width of the image represented by ByteBuffer
      height - height of the image represented by ByteBuffer
      filename - name of file
      Throws:
      IOException

    • registerGlyph

      void registerGlyph(String bitmapId, int c, int xoff, int yoff, int w, int h, float u0, float v0, float u1, float v1)
      Register a single Character Glyph for later rendering.
      Parameters:
      c - the character
      xoff - xoffset in the bitmap
      yoff - yoffset in the bitmap
      w - the width of the glyph
      h - the height of the glyph
      u0 - the x texture coordinates of the upper left point
      v0 - the y texture coordinates of the upper left point
      u1 - the x texture coordinates of the bottom right point
      v1 - the y texture coordinates of the bottom right point

    • prepare

      void prepare()
      This is called after all registerBitmap() and registerGlyph() calls are done. This can be used to do more initialization prior to actual rendering calls.

    • beforeRender

      void beforeRender(Object customRenderState)
      This is called before several render() calls are happening. This method can be used to set up state for upcoming text rendering calls or it might allow the implementation to cache state between render() states (f.i. texture state).
      Parameters:
      customRenderState - some user object provided by JGLFont.setCustomRenderState() or null

    • preProcess

      int preProcess(String text, int offset)
      This allows any pre-processing of the next characters to happen. You're given the complete text and the current offset. You should then process the text beginning from the given offset. If you find something interesting you can do whatever you like with the characters. You can even skip characters that should be excluded from the rendering by return a new offset where the rendering should continue. Nifty-GUI uses this feature to handle the Nifty-GUI specific color encoding that starts with a \# sequence.
      Parameters:
      text - the complete text to render
      offset - the offset where the next characters will get rendered
      Returns:
      the new offset

    • render

      void render(String bitmapId, int x, int y, int c, float sx, float sy, float r, float g, float b, float a)
      Render a single character at the given position with the given color using the given bitmapId.
      Parameters:
      bitmapId - the bitmapId the corresponding character is on
      x - the x position
      y - the y position
      c - the character codepoint to output
      sx - x scale factor
      sy - y scale factor
      r - red
      g - green
      b - blue
      a - alpha

    • afterRender

      void afterRender()
      This is called after several render() calls.

    • preProcessForLength

      int preProcessForLength(String text, int offset)
      This allows any pre-processing of the next characters to happen when the width of a text is to be calculated. This is mainly used to skip characters f.i. when color encoded characters are contained in the String that should not be used for string width calculations.
      Parameters:
      text - the complete text to render
      offset - the offset where the next characters will get rendered
      Returns:
      the new offset
